results.title: Blackberry subway jam
results.creator_credit: Robert Doucet, Douglas MacDonald, Eunice Macaulay and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Animated version of the popular children’s story by Robert Munsch is about a young boy with a major problem: his apartment has become a subway station but his mother doesn’t believe him and blames him for the commuters’ mess. Jonathan takes his problem to City Hall and gets his first look at what bureaucratic bungling is all about. Munsch’s story is entitled Jonathan Cleaned Up—Then He Heard a Sound. Music by Alex Pauk. Voice and narration by Hannah Goodheart.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Doucet, Douglas MacDonald, Eunice Macaulay and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Blackbeard's ghost
results.creator_credit: Robert Stevenson and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: The legendary pirate Blackbeard is cursed to wander in limbo until he performs a good deed. He gets his chance when he decides to help a local college track team that hasn’t a ghost of a chance of winning! Cast includes Peter Ustinov, Dean Jones, Suzanne Pleshette, Elsa Lanchester. Based on the book by Ben Stahl.

results.title: Blade runner [Director's cut]
results.creator_credit: Ridley Scott, Michael Deeley, Bud Yorkin, Jerry Perenchio, Ladd Company and Sir Run Run Shaw
results.brief_description: Ridley Scott’s adaptation of Philip K. Dick’s novel “Do androids dream of electric sheep” has rapidly become a classic of the science fiction genre. In Los Angeles, 2019, Deckard, a licensed-to-kill cop is given the task of tracking down and destroying a group of intelligent androids who have hijacked a space shuttle and returned to Earth. In the process Deckard has to confront disturbing questions about what makes a human being. “A richly detailed and visually overwhelming trip to the future which sticks with you like a recurrent nightmare.” Starring Harrison Ford, Rutger Hauer and Sean Young.

results.title: Black tide
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: As a coastal dwelling nation, Australia has a lot to lose from any large oil spills. So far the nation has not suffered major sea pollution problems comparable with some maritime nations. As a form of protection of Australian waters against oil pollution, a co-ordinated National Plan has been devised by government agencies to be actioned immediately a threat of pollution arises. This film, sponsored by the Commonwealth Department of Transport describes the extent of that plan to protect Australian coastal ecosystems and economics. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Black music in America: from then till now
results.creator_credit: Hugh A Robertson, Richard Kerns, William H. Barnett and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Presents the history of black people’s contribution to American music from the pioneer days until 1970. Features among others; Louis Armstrong, Mahalia Jackson, Duke Ellington, Count Bassie, Nina Simone and what is reported to be the only footage of Bessie Smith.

results.title: Bitter paradise: The Sellout of East Timor
results.brief_description: Prior to Indonesian invasion and subsequent occupation, Portugese East Timor was a country far removed from external influences. Anthropologists from the west visted the country as an example of a preserved culture. Canadian tourist and photographer, Elaine Briere, visited in 1974; her photos remain as some of the only documents that attest to the peaceful existence of the country prior to invasion. Briere presents a harsh case against Western society, in particular Canada, and their complicity in allowing the military elite of the Suharto government to invade East Timor. A move that was motivated by a desire to control raw material and exploit new markets. Briere’s photographs and the testimonies provided by East Timorese who survived to tell of the atrocities that occurred are compiled as a photo documentary of the solidarity movement. More than anything, this documentary is a moving tribute to a country with a determination to maintain their independence and culture from assimilation, as well as promoting awareness of the East Timor occupation. Warning: This documentary contains scenes which may offend some viewers.

results.title: Bitter coffee = Secangkir kopi pahit
results.creator_credit: Teguh Karya, Bambang Widitomo, Njoohan Siang and Sanggar Film
results.brief_description: In one of his finest works, Teguh Karya takes an inside look at the lives of working-class ethnic Bataks in Indonesia through the film’s main character, Togar. The film opens with Togar being arrested after his wife has drowned, with the remainder of the film being told in flashbacks. The story unfolds with Togar having gone to Jakarta to pursue his ambition of being a journalist and meeting an older divorced woman at a local foodstall. He is subsequently forced to marry her when it turns out she is pregnant, only to find out later the child might not be his. He forgives his wife however and takes her, together with her children, back to his village in Jogjakarta to meet his mother, the setting of the unfortunate drowning accident. The film provides an interesting window into the lives of many such Indonesians like Togar as well as the city of Jakarta and its influence on those that live there. Cast includes Rina Hassim, Ray Sahetapy, Dewi Yull and Alex Komang. In Indonesian with English subtitles.

results.title: Black Magic (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This is a film about sport and top Aboriginal sportsmen. It is predominantly an account of the creative use of sport made by the Noongar people of Western Australia’s south-west to advance their status. Through interviews with top sportsmen like the Krakouer brothers in the Victorian Football League and Archie Jones, the runner of the 1920s, the film establishes that the motivation to succeed in sport arises from a moral desire to be accepted and recognised.
